text: Oh path heritage oh you've done an intro
like this already hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for an
album review and of all the requests
that I get all the time this review is
kind of become a highly highly
anticipated review oh pets heritage now
these guys are a Swedish rock band known
mostly for their interpretations of
progressive metal and progressive death
metal but I've never ever ever ever ever
been an Opeth fan never their melodic
and and to me kind of overproduced take
on death metal just has never ever done
anything for me I know that's gonna piss
some people off because opeth has kind
of become over the years through a
consistent style and a lot of releases
become this metal sacred cow but on this
new LP heritage Opeth throws away all
death metal and even just metal in
general sounds for this record and just
makes a really complete and an honest
and Breece of progressive rock now it's
not like that's anything new for these
guys they've done that once before on
2003's damnation and some of the quieter
moments on this new LP actually reminds
me of 2002's deliverance a little bit at
least that's what I think even though
Opeth has played in this area before
this album is getting a lot of mixed
reviews and I'm not completely sure why
I'm not a huge fan of this LP either I
don't think it's gonna be for the same
reasons that
Opeth fans are the band's frontman whose
name coucher chesta is going to
pronounce nikhil Ecker fileted tim has
put his death growls away for this album
but i don't see how that would ruin it I
mean I don't think it's just simply his
growls that were bringing opeth fans to
the table to me Opeth on this album
they're embracing in
older shade of progressive rock to me
this album is like totally King Crimson
it's totally jethro tull it's even a
little Mahavishnu it points especially
in the drums these these drums on this
record are fantastic they're just these
jazz fusion drums with these you know
hard-hitting rolls and fills but you
know you've got these jazzy ride cymbals
and great grooves flowing underneath a
lot of these tracks I like the texture
of the guitars on this thing - they've
got a nice edge to them but they don't
come off like just distorted and blaring
like your average metal guitar I mean it
even sounds like a kind of close friend
of the band Steven Wilson from porcupine
tree had a bit of an influence on this
record since there are moments on here
that remind me of songs off Steve
Wilson's new solo album and I like how
tight up at the sounding on this album -
especially the second single that these
guys dropped this year The Devil's
orchard the syncopated drums guitars an
organ on that track are great they just
sound so badass in the way that organ
just colors the background with this
just sinister sinister sound is nice the
band shows a lot of dynamics and a lot
of interplay as they transition from
these latter moments to these softer
moments they just it just happened so
gracefully to me it's not like there's a
heart in or a heart out or it's really
obvious it's like I don't know where the
band is going or what they're going to
do until they finally get there
especially tracks like I feel the dark
which start off with vocals acoustic
guitar but then they subtly grow into
bass drums keys in the background and
then when this main booming guitar riff
just punches in it's like this nice shot
of progressive rock adrenaline I think a
lot of the tracks on here of interesting
song structures it's just not your
average verse chorus verse but like I
said I'm not really a fan of this album
and it has a lot to do with just one
single thing have you ever had an entire
album ruined for you because you're not
into one single thing on the
I'm just one sound that they keep using
or or one instrument or or just one way
they mix the drums or something I've
never been into Opeth vocals sadly I
just I just have not the growls have
been pretty good in the past but the
cleans just do nothing for me and this
album is nothing but cleans the vocals
have a good range there on pitch I can't
take that away from them that's fine
that's fine but it's just whatever
technical term you want to slap on it
the the tambour of the vocals the
cadence the inflection just the the
sound of them they just sound like your
average modern hardrock vocals to me it
sounds like this is a voice I would hear
if I went out to the local bar to hear
the best cover band in town that's not
really the issue I mean there's little
there's a larger problem for me and
that's that to me the vocals just don't
feel urgent to me they don't feel
emotional to me they just don't grab me
they don't captivate me they don't pull
me in let's take one of the first big
thematic lyrics from this album comes
off the devil's orchard god is dead god
is dead it's repeated a bunch of times
God is dead one of the most revered
figures in history is dead shouldn't I
feel something or think something when I
hear this being said this line sounds
like it's being sung in a local musical
theater production the vocals just hit
the right notes that's all I can say
they do they just don't convey any
emotional highs or lows to me they never
feel really depressing or really soft or
you know really dark and they never feel
really intense they never feel really in
my face or thrilling I know I like the
way the band is playing on this LP I
know I like the style that they're
embracing but to me the vocals are just
such a central part of this album I know
a lot of Opeth fans may have already
decided how they feel on this album and
that's fine but if you've never been an
opah fan I would at least try this thing
out because they are trying something
different on this LP if you've been
turned off by album
like Blackwater park or something like
that in the past then this is definitely
worth trying because it is a different
flavor different direction
I'm feeling a light too decent five on
this one it was alright
on the fence with it just not really
loving it
not really hating it but what do you
